title: Doesn't it seem like there are alot of things missing in itemization?
body:
For one, barring a few specific champs, usually you just build the same thing depending on your role.  Marksmen almost all end up with the same 4-5 items, tanks get to change it up sort of, but basically the enemy team comp chooses their build for them since there aren't enough options to have much variety apart from the core.  If you want health the most you'll probably have the same build as any tank that wants health most, same goes for armor and MR.  For mages it seems like either you're tanky or not, and unless you have a manaless champ you'll probably end up with the same items as any other mage that chooses the same route.

  While pushing more diversity in the champs themselves, the items seem to be getting narrowed more and more.   Some examples:  Why are there no MR/Mana items anymore?  Why is building mana the only way to get CDR on an armor item?  If a tank needs attack speed and tankiness, why is wit's end the only option?  Why is crit only on glass cannon items now?  Some of these things seem very strange.  Tanks/bruisers who need attack speed still need attack speed when they are not facing much magic damage, but Wit's End has been the only option for years.  Some champs don't use mana, so when they need CDR and armor they are forced to buy two seperate items for it and that doesn't work out too well most of the time(if you need cdr, health, AND armor... well damn :) ).  I think part of it is where they don't mind axing an item completely if it doesn't get much use.  That doesn't seem like the right way to go at all.  For example, what did Atma's actually hurt about the game?  If it's only good on one or two champs but isn't broken, there isn't really a need to remove the option.  It just shoehorns everyone into the same build over time when you remove the more obscure or less used options.

  It gets very boring to feel like there's a static build for just about every role that you might swap out one item on occasionally.  I know they have been pretty reluctant to add new items to the game but i think this is something that's getting more and more important the way the game is going.  There should never only be one viable way to build a character.  If that's the case, the items become more of a mandatory chore than a build choice.

replies.body: There are meta strong picks, there always have been. But nothing is mandatory. There are core items, choice items, situational items, playstyle picks and more. Only ADCs and a couple other specific champions are extremely narrow.

What I mean is, if you take a champ and ask 'what stats do i need?' you'll end up buying the same items for the same stats on nearly everyone who wants it.  Champs are so drastically different from each other that the same core items don't support them all the same way.  Throw defense into the mix and your options get narrowed down even more.  If you're building tanky and the enemy team is heavily leaning on either AP or AD, barring one item here and there you're going to end up with the same build as any other tanky champ.  Sure there isn't much that's absolutely mandatory, but when choosing any other option reduces your ability to do what you're trying to do, then it's not really a viable choice.

Adding more niche items could open up plenty of build options, and fits better with the base idea of the game(pick a champ and mold them how you want).  If it's simply impossible to balance items for the vast number of champs, then perhaps items are not the right way to go.  They already support snowballing far too much, and nobody likes automatically losing a fight because someone across the map and out of their control died too much.

There's ... kind of a reason for that. If a tank ( or, worse, a diver or juggernaut ) could easily get their hand on everything they wanted for bulk early, it'd be pathetically easy for them to become nigh-unkillable mid-game before the damage dealers get a chance to significantly outskill defenses with no real holes in their armor.

Not to mention mixed damage dealers really are reliant on the difficulty of itemizing defensively against them, because they can't effectively opt into penetration - so late game, their damage won't scale as well against bulky targets, unlike damage dealers that focus on a single type.

Plus, everyone would opt into bulk mixed defenses if it was an effective thing to do, outside of games where there really is only one damage type that will pose a significant threat. It's hard to appreciate if you're just playing without thinking too much about it, but you really do get a ton of bulk out of the current items against the appropriate damage type.

If you haven't noticed, AP gets a helluva lot more offensive + defensive itemization than AD does, mostly because, well, AP is strictly worse offensively from a design standpoint.

No champion gets innate value from AP, whereas all champions get innate value from AD. In fact, AP does _literally nothing_ on several champions unless they build items specifically to have an AP scaling. In addition to that, AP has far less multipliers than AD does - no AP-building champion has any abilities that skill with both crit and AP, and very few have AP scaling abilities that are affected by attack speed in the slightest. Not to mention the attack speed has a far, far higher cap than the typical AP user's equivalent, cooldown reduction.

Add to that that the innate value from AD has absolutely no cost at all ( outside of Jhin and Graves ) and naturally has a smaller base cooldown than basically any ability in the game, and it's really no surprise that AP gets some boons with its items that AD items couldn't dream of.

There's other facets to it, too, but that's one of the main ones.

But when you have so many items, it tends to get to the point where if you don't build these 3 items to counter these 3 damage dealing champions, you're a terrible tank.
